Core Course: Global Reform and Privatization of Public Enterprises
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Fumika Ouchi Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-5085
Number 19 October 1998
Petkoski, Djordjija (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
The Regulatory Reform and Private Enterprise Division of EDI (EDIRP) conducted a core course on Global Reform and Privatization of Public Enterprises in Washington, D.C., from June 21-26, 1998. The main goal of the course was to expose participants to the recent concepts and practices of enterprise reform and privatization and enhance their capabilities to develop and implement privatization and restructuring programs at the national and corporate levels. The course had 4 specific objectives, including exploring the meaning of client focus, providing an overview of privatization, exploring conditions for successful public enterprise reform and privatization, and implementation of privatization. Twenty-eight participants attended this course, consisting of university professors, government policy makers and business leaders from the Former Soviet Union, Mongolia, and China, as well as graduate students from the Columbia University's Economic Policy and Management Program.
The course was evaluated by the EDI Evaluation Unit (EDIES) using a Participants' Feedback Questionnaire. The Questionnaire was completed by 25 respondents, 89.3% of the total participants. Six respondents (24%) were from the Former Soviet Union, 1 (4%) respondent from Mongolia, 10 (40%) from China, and 8 (32%) from Columbia University. Respondents were asked to rate the achievement of the course objectives, effectiveness of instruction, and usefulness of the case studies. A 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1=minimum to 5=maximum was used for each question. The quality of the course lecturers was evaluated on a scale that ranged from excellent, good, average, poor, to very poor. Respondents' written comments about the course performance were also content analyzed. Following is a summary of the evaluation findings.
l The overall usefulness of the course received a mean score of 4.60 on a 5-point scale. This was the highest rating of all course performance indicators in the evaluation. The percentage of respondents who rated 4 or 5 was 100% for those from the Former Soviet Union and Mongolia (mean=5.0) and China (mean=4.80). Seventy-five percent of the 8 Columbia students also gave 4 or 5 on this indicator (mean=4.0).
l There was a general consensus among respondents that the course achieved two specific objectives. One was the provision of a framework for global reform and privatization (mean=4.46) and the other was the course's emphasis on being client focused (mean=4.28). The respondents from China felt that the course was particularly successful in providing a basis for designing similar country-specific training programs (mean=4.60).
l Of the 6 case studies presented in the course, the Columbia students found the YPE Sociedad and Argentinean Integrated most useful (mean=4.0). Their ratings of other 5 case studies were in the mid-3.0 range. Respondents from the Former Soviet Union,  Mongolia and China indicated that the case studies were very satisfactory, giving a mean score of over 4.50 on all case studies except one item (Bolivia Experience). Lessons from Hungary received the highest score from these respondents, 4.80 from the Chinese respondents and the maximum score, 5.0, from the Former Soviet Union (FSU) and Mongolian respondents.
lResults indicated respondents' high approval ratings of course lectures. When converted to a numerical measurement scale ranging from excellent=5 and very poor=1, the mean scores of a total of 11 lecturers ranged between 4.16 and 4.79 out of 5.0. Six lectures received a rating of 4 or 5 from all respondents. Respondents evaluated the course lectures by using a scale that descended in the level of performance from maximum (=excellent) to minimum (=very poor). The use of two different scales may have introduced a bias and lent uncertainty to the results.
lThe degree of respondents' learning was measured by one question on how much respondents learned about each of 10 specific subjects, asked only at the end of the course. No pre-course measure of learning was taken. The mean scores of the Former Soviet Union and Mongolian respondents were in the 4.0-4.86 range on a 5- point scale. Chinese respondents also had very high ratings, all items exceeding 4.0 except for one item on private participation in infrastructure (mean=3.90). Responses from Columbia students were relatively lower and mixed, ranging between 3.17 (Financial sector and SOE reform) and 4.14 (Corporate governance).
lThree suggestions for the course were made in respondents' written comments. These were the need for more country-specific studies from China and Central Asia (N=7), more emphasis on issues of corporate governance, competition, and bankruptcy as a result of privatization (N=8), and the roles of government, including ways to maintain transparency in the privatization process, and successful models of legislation (N=4).
lOverall, the ratings on the feedback Questionnaire were high across questions, except for those rated by the Columbia students. The percentage of respondents who chose the maximum scores, such as 4 or 5 on a 5-point scale, was 100% for 19 out of 21 response categories among those from the Former Soviet Union and Mongolia, and 90% or higher for those from China. This may be due to the course content and its emphasis on practical aspects of implementation, rather than theoretical issues of privatization and reform of public enterprises.
lThere were two limitations to the evaluation. First, there was no indicator measuring the respondents' knowledge at the beginning of the course. The degree to which the course may have contributed to their understanding of the course topics was, therefore, not evaluated. It is suggested that a set of cognitive-based questions be included in the questionnaire to assess changes in their knowledge before and after the course. Second, demographic information was not available in the Questionnaire. A gender question, for example, may have been useful to see whether the 12 (43%) women who participated in the course had similar responses and feedback as men about the course.
